text: Delta is not a good approximation for probability of being in the money under two conditions. And I'm going to show you. First, let's take a look at spy. If we go out 39 days, we go to a 30 delta option right here. The 30 delta would tell you about a 30 probability of being in the money at expiration. And if we go over and we look at the actual calculated probability, which is different, it shows this 28.14. So it's pretty dang close, right off by 2.2 cares. Well, let's now go out further. Let's go to 16 Jan, which is 249 days out. Let's go to that same 30 delta, 29 delta close enough. This would tell us 29 probability of being in the money at expiration. And this one instead has 25. So what just happened? We're in one of the most liquid underlines that exist. And what you just learned is that if you go further out in time, the relationship starts to break down more. Now again, this is still close enough because it's super liquid, not very volatile, which is the next key component. Let's take a look at Tesla. If we do the same exercise, let's first do the 39 DTE. And we do the 30 delta. You'll notice 30 delta, 30 chance being in the money at expiration. This is instead 23.7. That's a pretty big difference. This is actually bigger difference than what you saw in spy going further

There are two things that skew using delta is the probability. Volatility is one. Second is duration. This is why it is typically still good practice to just use this separate calculation.
